q: How can erythromelalgia be controlled?
a: To control erythromelalgia symptoms and avoid flare-ups, you can try wearing loose clothing and shoes, drinking plenty of fluids, managing stress, cooling down your hands or feet with a fan or cool (not cold) gel pack, and raising your hands or feet on a chair or pillow during a flare-up. Avoid cooling down your hands or feet with cold water or using ice, as this can damage your skin. Also, avoid consuming alcohol or eating spicy food.

q: What are the symptoms of erythromelalgia?
a: The main symptoms of erythromelalgia are burning pain, redness (which may appear different on brown or black skin), and warm or hot skin. Other symptoms can include swelling and increased sweating. The pain can be constant or come and go in flare-ups lasting from a few minutes to a few days. After a flare-up, the skin may feel cold and appear blue or grey.

q: What causes erythromelalgia?
a: The exact cause of erythromelalgia is often unknown, but it can sometimes be caused by another underlying condition or a faulty gene inherited from a parent. Flare-ups of symptoms are triggered by an increase in body temperature, which can be caused by factors like exercise, wearing warm or tight clothes and shoes, warm temperatures, stress, alcohol consumption, eating spicy food, or dehydration.

q: How is erythromelalgia diagnosed?
a: If a GP suspects erythromelalgia, they will refer you to a specialist who will examine you and ask about your symptoms. The specialist may also conduct tests such as blood tests and genetic testing to look for changes in your genes that may be causing your symptoms.

q: What treatments are available for erythromelalgia?
a: The treatment for erythromelalgia depends on the underlying cause. If another condition is causing your symptoms, treating that condition can help. Treatment aims to prevent flare-ups and can involve various medications (creams, gels, sprays, tablets, or intravenous), as well as surgery in rare cases. It may require trying different combinations of treatments to find what works best for you.

q: How can I get NHS help for my erythromelalgia-related pain?
a: If your erythromelalgia symptoms are impacting your mental health, cognitive-behavioral therapy and counseling can be helpful. For information on getting NHS help for your pain, you can find resources and support from the NHS.

a: To find more information about erythromelalgia, you can visit The Erythromelalgia Association which provides resources and support to empower individuals living with the condition.
